Description.val: This line item funds the modifications to the Adversary aircraft.  The Adversary aircraft are a combination of 43 F-5 Tiger IIs (40 F-5Ns and 3 F-5Fs), and Block 15 F-16 Fighting Falcon (10 F-16As and 4 F-16Bs), and the J85 Engine supporting  the F-5F/N.  The Adversary aircraft provide essential sorties in support of TOPGUN, Fleet Replacement Squadron, Carrier Strike Group, Carrier Air Wing and Unit Deployment Plan training both the F-5s and the F-16s are planned to be used as primary Adversary mission through 2035.

Justification.val: FY 2021 funding reflects the modification of (22) F-5 aircraft purchased from the government of Switzerland into the USN configuration under OSIP 017-17 and creation of the F-16 Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) under OSIP 011-21.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Organic Maintenance Facility Hill Air Force Depot:: Installation Name: Falcon UP Kits

Description.val:
This OSIP incorporates the Falcon Up structural enhancement modification in 10 Navy F-16A Adversary aircraft.  The Falcon Up modification is a safety modification that replaces known airframe fatigue sensitive structure.  Incorporation of the Falcon Up kit extends the airframe service life from 3,665 flight hours to 4,250 flight hours and will extend the service life until approximately 2025.

Development Status/major milestones:  The structural components on the Falcon Up kit have been qualified by the Air Force and approved for Navy use.  No operational testing is required.  A first article test, consisting of nondestructive critical measurements is complete.  A firm fixed price contract for kits was awarded.  The kits have been produced and delivered.  The aircraft modification has been done as a drive in mod at Hill Air Force Depot and is complete.

ModificationTitle.val: F-5 System Safety and Sustainability OSIP 017-17

Name.@footnote: Increase in FY 2021 provides other support for Swiss aircraft reconfiguration efforts.  Increase in FY 2022 provides other support for the installation of these efforts.
Increase in FY 2021 provides logistic support for Swiss aircraft reconfiguration efforts.
Increase in FY 2021 and FY 2022 procures support equipment applicable to the Swiss reconfiguration aircraft.

Title.val: F-5 System Safety and Sustainability OSIP 017-17

Name.@footnote: ARC 210 efforts will be consolidated into the Cockpit Display Upgrade Val/Ver.
Procurement of the A Kits associated with previously integrated ECPs applicable to the USN configuration but not currently integrated on the Swiss aircraft.
Current ECP's are funded by PMA 209 for the existing fleet of 43 aircraft.  This effort will fund the procurement of 22 additional ECP's for the Swiss aircraft.
Procurement of the B Kits associated with previously integrated ECPs applicable to the USN configuration but not currently integrated on the Swiss aircraft.
Cost element funds initial non-recurring engineering in support of the reconfiguration of the 22 Swiss aircraft into the USN configuration.
Cost element funds initial non-recurring engineering in support of the integration of the cockpit Display Upgrade in the 22 Swiss aircraft.
Cost element funds the integration of the new cockpit display into the existing F-5 simulator.

Description.val:
This Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds modifications to F-5 aircraft to implement safety updates as well as required upgrades to avionic systems for Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) compliance.

This OSIP includes efforts that address modifications to address safety, reliability, structural integrity, mission availability, maintainability, weapon system employment, obsolescence, and Diminishing Manufacturing Source (DMSMS) requirements. Modifications include Airframe, sub-systems, weapon system, and avionics systems. Modifications, particularly to avionic systems, may also be driven by new cyber security requirements.

Initiatives include, but are not limited to: Stability Augmentation Components Assembly (SACA) Obsolescence ECPs, LN-260 Display Upgrades, Integrated ARC 210 Radios, Swiss Aircraft Reconfiguration to USN standard.


DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: 
The LN 260 Display and ARC 210 efforts have been consolidated into the Cockpit Display Val/Ver.  Swiss Reconfiguration NRE and kit procurement scheduled to begin in FY 2021 with installations starting in FY 2022.

Name.@footnote: Cost element funds other support for F-16 Falcon STAR and Cockpit Display Upgrade efforts.  Increase in FY 2022 provides other support related to the cockpit upgrade, radar, and F100 replacement.  Increase in FY 2023 & 2024 is associated with lab and flight testing of the integrated STAR and cockpit configuration.
Cost element funds integrated logistics support for F-16 Falcon STAR and Cockpit Display Upgrade efforts.
Cost element funds initial support equipment applicable to F-16 for Falcon STAR and Cockpit Display Upgrade efforts.
Cost element funds incorporation of all configuration changes and maintenance requirements applicable for F-16 Falcon STAR and Cockpit Display Upgrade efforts.

Name.@footnote: Cost element provides non-recurring engineering for the integration and installation of the cockpit upgrade in the F-16 (A) in FY 2022.  The non-recurring engineering for the F-16 (B) integration will be funded in FY 2023.
Cost element funds the non-recurring engineering in support of the integration of the cockpit display into a new F-16  STAR simulator.

Description.val:
The F-16 Service Life Extension Program (SLEP) Operational Safety Improvement Program (OSIP) funds the modifications to the (10) F-16A, (4) F-16B Adversary aircraft required to maintain sufficient aircraft inventory to meet fleet operational requirements.  These modifications will increase the service life from 4,250 flight hours to 8,000 equivalent flight hours and extend service life through airframe strengthening, avionics upgrades, and just in time modifications to prevent aircraft grounding due to fatigue.  Modifications include, but are not limited to, upgrading the airframe, upgrading the avionics, and modification of F100 engines.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:
The structural components have been qualified by the Air Force and approved for Navy Use.  Non-Recurring Engineering (NRE) for the avionic upgrade scheduled to commence in FY21.  Installation kit production purchases planned to start in FY22 with a 12-month delivery time.  Installations will be performed as a Depot mod.
